moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 d5 3. e3 Bg4 4. Be2 Nc6: I've been experimenting with the Zukertort-type setup.
moves.6... Bd6 7. Nbd2 O-O 8. O-O Bh5 9. Ne5 B: This was probably a mistake.  I think Nxc6 was better here, giving Black an isolated a-pawn.  I could have followed with f4 if desired, or also Nf3.
moves.11... Ndxe5 12. fxe5 Be7 13. a3: Black's N is largely out of play, but White has little ability to generate a Kingside attack.
moves.13... f5 14. Rf3: I think exf6 e.p. would have given White better attacking chances.
moves.14... Bh4 15. Raf1 a6 16. Rh3: The R is horribly misplaced here and takes forever to get back into play.
moves.16... g6 17. c4: This diversion is way to early.  I should figure out how to get a grip on the c-file first if I am going to open it up.
White has traded into a terrible position.  Nf3 has no good squares.  Rh3 is virtually out of play.  Bb2 has a blocked diagonal and no scope.  Black's pieces are much better.
moves.22. Nd2 b5 23. Rc1: This is the only useful diagonal.
moves.23... Nxe5: This was a nice tactical shot that I actually missed.  If White plays dxe5, Black plays Rxd2 with tempo.
moves.24. Rxc7 Re8 25. e4 Rd7 26. Rc2: This might not have been best either.  Rxd7, Nxd7, Rc3 would have seized the file anyway.
moves.26... Nf7 27. e5 Bg5 28. Nf3 Be3+ 29. Kf: Now the position is blocked up.  No one has much play.
